snippet.textDisplay: Just one thing, when hanging your hand down loosely from the shoulders, the fingers do not curve as extreme as you suggested when talking about the 2+3 trill. Thus tugging in finger 3-5 like you suggest is not their natural position, but it certainly avoids the shaking associated with them being held above the keys. And their is nothing inherently wrong with them giggling along during the 2-3 trill. But I agree that it looks more elegantly the way you do it.  If the trill is short however, I would rest the fingers above the keys and let them giggle along so they are ready for their next task. Just a thought.

snippet.textDisplay:
I know this is a tongue in cheek comment. But really, practicing 9hrs a day is terrible advice, especially because it's (what you practice and how you practice more than how much you practice. Besides 9hrs a day would be sustainable for maybe a week or so at most...now if you just mean overall playing amount/per day you are correct. (Playing 9hrs per day and practing 9hrs/day are 2 very different things). An average of 2-3 hrs/day of practice (on average over many many years is the best way to go for sustainable playing over a time of decades.
Temporary bouts of 5-6 hrs /day will be good for closing gaps to next levels of technique and such, but again it's not sustainable forever. All of this advice is of course geared towards someone who wants to become a professional. If this is not the goal, then an HR or maybe 2hrs at most a few times a week will be more than sufficient.

snippet.textDisplay: I prefer to also do that because it seems to help me keep my hand in a balanced position. There's a picture of Hofmann's hand at the piano where he's doing it with a subtitle along the lines of 'correct finger positioning'. If you're playing fast passages and your little finger is sticking up as demonstrated in this video, curling your little finger reduces unnecessary hand movements and makes the whole thing a lot easier (in my experience). [By the way, it must not be tense - if you want to tuck it under, absolutely stay relaxed]

snippet.textDisplay:
here's a few tips for how to learn piano
Try practicing about an hour each day, or even 1/2 an hour if you can't find time.
Do extra practice whenever you can. For example, on weekends you can do more than 1 hour, perhaps 2 or three, or even more.
(I discovered about these and more from Denelle piano lesson website )

snippet.textDisplay:
The minor pentatonics are good...they're sparse so you have to change positions a lot...very little thumb under. Here's C minor- C, Eb, F, G, Bb, (C). And here's the 2 octave, C minor, RH fingering- 1 2 3 1 2 3 4 1 2 4 5.

Here's Eb minor--

1 2 3 4 1 2 4 1 2 4 5. That fingering also works for these minor pents: Ami, Dmi, E mi, B mi and G mi.

For all these and the other jazz scales plus positional playing, see the Marius Nordal book at the Sher Publishing site.
snippet.textOriginal:
The minor pentatonics are good...they're sparse so you have to change positions a lot...very little thumb under. Here's C minor-  C, Eb, F, G, Bb, (C).  And here's the 2 octave, C minor, RH  fingering-  1 2 3    1 2 3 4   1 2 4 5.    

Here's Eb minor--

1 2  3 4    1  2  4   1  2  4  5.   That fingering also works for these minor pents:  Ami, Dmi, E mi,  B mi and G mi.

For all these and the other jazz scales plus positional playing,  see the   Marius Nordal book at the Sher Publishing site.

snippet.textDisplay:
Josh - Nice technique and I'll listen to more of your lessons.
In your video, when you say the word "flex," you are showing "extension" (straightening) of a finger or fingers rather than "flexing" the finger(s). "Flexing" is to have the finger or finger tips curl or bend toward the keyboard or palm of hand.
Have you, by the way, heard of a technique called, "the purl"?

snippet.textDisplay: Are you sure the wobbling exercise really makes the hand more neutral? From experiments on both myself and students, I find lifting fingers is a panic reflex to stop the whole palm falling down through a droopy and inert finger. Wobbling makes my finger stand up into more life, not more neutral. I also use conscious finger lifting to empower the standing finger into more action, before letting them dangle back down (while keeping the standing finger active and alive). I find this kind of conscious finger lifting is ironically the quickest cure for unwanted lifting. Once the playing fingers are keeping the hand open, with more action, the panic reflex vanishes. Drooping after producing tone is the underlying fault, which causes the panic.
snippet.textOriginal: Are you sure the wobbling exercise really makes the hand more neutral? From experiments on both myself and students, I find lifting fingers is a panic reflex to stop the whole palm falling down through a droopy and inert finger. Wobbling makes my finger stand up into more life, not more neutral. I also use conscious finger lifting to empower the standing finger into more action, before letting them dangle back down (while keeping the standing finger active and alive). snippet.textDisplay:
@Winds of March Journey/Perry tribute band if you know your scales and arpeggios, you can transpose much easier. It's all about knowing where in the key your in the melody lies.

Another way to this is thinking about your melody as solfege notes instead. Then go to your new key and find the same solfege notes. Voila, you have transposed your melody.

snippet.textDisplay: After working through various technical difficulties of my own I have become convinced that the root of all technical problems is a lack of finger strength. When you ask a finger to do something that it is not strong enough to do, the OTHER fingers around it will do strange and unexpected things in an attempt to help the struggling finger. They will tense up or 'fly away' or perhaps your wrist will break or you'll drop a shoulder or hunch your back or tense up in some other way. This is why when you start working on a new piece you will sometimes find your fingers doing unexpected and bizarre things. Things you've never seen them do before. I think the problem is not with the finger(s) that are tense or flying away, but with some other finger which is too weak for what is required at that point in the piece. You can see this same kind of problem in all other physical activities (sports) where technique breaks down because of weakness. This is why all sports have strength and conditioning programs during the off season. They understand that strength is the foundation for good technique in any physical endeavor. Find your weakness, fix your weakness, and your technical problems will go away. The stronger you are the easier it is to relax. If you are weak you won't be able to relax. As you get stronger you will discover that it is easier to find your muscles and relax them and still play.

snippet.textDisplay: I find exercises which focus on finger independence very helpful. In particular Schmitt, and Pischna.  Another good exercise is placing 5 fingers on CDEFG,  and holding fingers 1,3,5 down (CEG) and playing 2,4 (D,F) as legato as possible and close to the keys. Then inverting. Anything that make a you have to think about your fingers individually will definitely help.   Once again,  great video!

snippet.textDisplay: I have a problem where the pinky on my right hand is inextricably linked to an extent to the fourth finger (I cannot hold the pinky down individually without affecting the fourth finger, and I cannot lift the fourth finger very much up individually without raising the pinky). It's impossible for me to "tuck" the pinky while playing the fourth finger like Horowitz (I can do it on the left hand). Is it still possible to eliminate the pinky lift given my physiological restriction (short of surgery??)
snippet.textOriginal: I have a problem where the pinky on my right hand is inextricably linked to an extent to the fourth finger (I cannot hold the pinky down individually without affecting the fourth finger, and I cannot lift the fourth finger very much up individually without raising the pinky). It's impossible for me to "tuck" the pinky while playing the fourth finger like Horowitz (I can do it on the left hand). Is it still possible to eliminate the pinky lift given my physiological restriction (short of surgery??)

snippet.textDisplay: @acediac1 Yes - try practicing Schmitt Preparatory exercises, specifically the ones that have you hold down the fourth finger. Then do the ones where you have to hold the fifth finger. These finger independence exercises should help :)
snippet.textOriginal: @acediac1 Yes - try practicing Schmitt Preparatory exercises, specifically the ones that have you hold down the fourth finger. Then do the ones where you have to hold the fifth finger. These finger independence exercises should help :)
